Welcome Ms. Iris Kolodji, Healy Choir--all the way from Kathmandu, Nepal!

"My name is Iris Kolodji; I am very excited to be joining the Pierz music team as the High School choir teacher for this coming school year!

Before this, I spent the last four years teaching music at the American International School in Kathmandu, Nepal. Outside of school, I was also the musical director for the Kathmandu Chorale, sang in a few groups around the city, and led the first Young People's Choir of Kathmandu.

With the pandemic, I found myself moving back to Minnesota and am excited to start laying down roots home again. I grew up in Northern Minnesota then moved to Minneapolis, where I lived during my time at the University of Minnesota.

When I am not singing and teaching, I enjoy trekking, Boundary Water Canoe trips, cooking and baking, yoga, cycling, music festivals, and traveling whenever and wherever I can.

I am looking forward to sharing music with this community and creating meaningful learning experiences with the students at Healy High School!"

Pierz Community Members— the School Garden is being run a new way this year. We normally sell shares to recover our costs but with CoVID19 we want to try a new method. We have the garden outlined with this tape. Help yourself to the produce and pay the school’s business office what you feel you can. Currently, we have broccoli, peas, radishes, kale, zucchini and spaghetti squash available. The raspberries and strawberries are nearly ready too. Please know that areas outside of the red and white tape are private citizens’ gardens that they labored in and are not to be touched.

As we start week two of distance learning, we would like to recognize the sacrifice our students are making everyday. Thank you, students, for giving your best during this difficult time. Gov. Tim Walz said it best during his State of the State address:

"As a dad and as a former teacher, I want to speak directly to our children for a moment.

I know this is scary. I know you miss seeing your teachers and your classmates. I know it's disappointing that many of the important end-of-school activities have been canceled. I know there are athletes out there who were prepared to go win state championships on diamonds and fields across the state.

But what you are doing matters. Your sacrifice is keeping people safe. You are protecting people. Someday when you have children of your own. You will tell them about this moment in history and what you did to help the people of your state. Thank you." - Minnesota Governor Tim Walz

Vaping (inhaling and exhaling the vapor produced by an electronic cigarette or similar device) is still a widespread issue amongst middle and high school youth.
Chief of Police Eric Hanneken has confiscated the pictured vaping devices this year alone at Healy High School.

Parents: please be aware of what these electronic vaping devices look like. They are small and oftentimes disguised as computer thumb-drives or even lighters.

Please be sure to check your children's phones, social media accounts, etc often and talk to them about appropriate and safe behavior online (and in real-life, too)

You could call it "The TikTok Talk" :)

TechTalk Tuesday from Screenagers: "For teens, ages 13 to 18, screen time has gone up by 42 minutes over the past four years. Teens now spend, on average, 7 hours and 22 minutes per day on screens, not including homework or schoolwork." These numbers came from a recent survey conducted by Common Sense Media.

"I am troubled by the fact that all these young kids now are building habits for their future. In the US, the average 8 to 12-year-old is spending 4 hours and 44 minutes on a screen per day, not including time spent at school for classwork or homework. And now so much of screen time is on a smartphone. The habits of wanting to be on, checking all the time, now start so much younger."

There is the parent-created movement, called Wait Until 8th, which encourages parents to take a pledge to wait until their child is in 8th grade to give them their own smartphone. Since its inception in 2017, they have 22,000 people who have taken the pledge. They have done an impressive job of spreading the word about what they are doing. Read on!
